6. Application. This section presents an application of our geometric approach to analyze brain connectivity patterns in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). ASD is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by abnormal social skills, communication skills, interests and behavior patterns [36, 24, 37]. A previous survey [5] observed the prevalence of ASD among children and showed that about 1 in 59 children worldwide has ASD. Thus, ASD has significantly affected the society and caused great economic burden for both patients' families and society [53]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop effective diagnostic and treatment methods.

Among available technologies, resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI) demonstrates potential for defining functional neurophenotypes [28, 63]. Many studies have utilized brain rs-fMRI data to develop classifiers to distinguish patients with ASD from typically developing controls (TDC) [1, 36]. In their methods, brain rs-FMRI data is typically transformed into correlation matrices to characterize brain connectivity patterns. This motivates us to use the proposed quotient geometry of correlation matrices for such brain connectivity study.

In our study, we collect data from the Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange I (ABIDE I) [18]. The ABIDE I contains 539 subjects with ASD and 573 TDCs from 17 international sites. In our study, we only use the data from a single site, Caltech, to reduce site-wise heterogeneity. Also, we use the preprocessed data provided by the the Preprocessed Connectome Project initiative [14]. Specifically, we choose the data processed with the Configurable Pipeline for the Analysis of Connectomes (CPAC), the procedures of which include slice time correction, motion correct, skull-strip, nuisance signal regression. Our study focuses on the time series data for regions of interest for the Harvard-Oxford Atlas. For each subject, we compute the covariance matrix of the time series and we delete the subject which has more than 8 zero diagonal entries in its covariance matrix. This leaves us 35 subjects with 18 ASDs and 17 TDCs. The average age of these subjects is 27.45 (with a std of 10.23), and the Male/Female ratio is $27 / 8$. Next, according to these subjects, we select all regions of interest where the associated time series exhibit non-zero variance for all subjects. This process results in 104 regions of interest.

In our study, we compute the correlation matrices for all subjects and these correlation matrices are of fixed rank 62. The consistent rank across all correlation matrices is a noteworthy observation, further justifying our use of the quotient geometry proposed in this paper. Next, we divide correlation matrices into two groups according to the ASD/TDC labels. For each group, we compute the Fréchet mean of correlation matrices using the orbit space structure with rank parameter equal to 62. These two mean correlation matrices are visualized in the first row of Figure 2. Then we compute the distance between these two mean correlation matrices, which is 3.69. Furthermore, we visualize the difference between these two mean correlation matrices in the second row of Figure 2. After thresholding the difference matrix at 0.2 , we find that the main differences between two mean correlation matrices are mostly concentrated in a subset of regions of interest. Thus, a further examination of these regions of interest from a biological perspective may be intriguing.
7. Conclusion. This paper provides a comprehensive theory on the quotient geometry of correlation matrices. We demonstrate that the set $\operatorname{Corr}(m,[k])$ of boundedrank correlation matrices admits a natural orbit space structure. Its stratification is determined by the rank of matrices. Moreover, its principal stratum $\operatorname{Corr}(m, k)$ has a compatible Riemannian quotient manifold structure. Both distance and Fréchet mean in the orbit space $\operatorname{Corr}(m,[k]) \equiv \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1} / \mathcal{O}(k)$ do not admit closed-form expression.

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Fig. 2. Heat maps of mean correlation matrices. In the first row, the left panel shows the mean correlation matrix for the ASD group, and the right panel shows the mean correlation matrix for the TDC group. In the second row, the left panel shows the difference of two mean correlation matrices (ASD - TDC), and the right panel shows the difference after thresholding at 0.2, i.e., setting those values in $[-0.2,0.2]$ to 0 .

Hence, our paper provides Riemannian optimization algorithms for efficient numerical computations of these two quantities. Moreover, we present theories on the minimizing geodesics in the orbit space, which are shown to have constant rank on the interior of the segment. Also, we delve into geometric quantities in the Riemannian quotient manifold $\Pi_{k}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1} / \mathcal{O}(k)$. We study concepts including horizontal and vertical spaces, Riemannian metric, injectivity radius, exponential and logarithmic map, curvatures, gradient and Hessian. Finally, we apply our geometric approach to an autism study and illustrate the utility of our method. To conclude, let us present several directions worthy of future study.

- First, it is intriguing to apply the proposed quotient geometry in various fields involving correlation matrices. For example, one may conduct a large-scale brain connectivity study using this geometry. Besides conducting tasks such as regression and classification, one can also take nonstationarity into account and investigate dynamic functional connectivity [36]. It is interesting to use advanced statistical tools designed for stratified spaces, such as stratified PCA [56] and central limit theorem for Fréchet mean on stratified spaces [40].
- Second, for general Fréchet regression [49], one may need to find the weighted

Fréchet mean with some negative weights $w_{i}$. Section 4.3 only addresses the case where all $w_{i}>0$. For general $w_{i}$, it is interesting to develop a suitable algorithm.

- Third, it is interesting to study general optimization over the set of correlation matrices of bounded rank. It is of interest to examine whether the algorithm in [46] can be extended to this case.
- Fourth, it is worth determining an expression for the horizontal life, the number of logarithms, and an expression for the curvature.
- Finally, since the product of spheres is symmetric, one can define Riemannian radial distributions on such space and develop estimation theory [12]. Thus, it is interesting to explore whether one can define radial distributions on orbit spaces and develop similar statistical theory.

Appendix A. Geometry. In this section, we review more geometric tools.
A.1. Diffeomorphism. A bijection $\Phi: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}$ between smooth manifolds $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$ is a diffeomorphism when both $\Phi$ and $\Phi^{-1}$ are differentiable. Proposition A. 1 provides a useful tool for establishing the differentiable property of a map.

Proposition A. 1 ([10], Proposition 6.1.2). Let $f$ be a submersion of a smooth manifold $\mathcal{M}$ to a smooth manifold $\mathcal{N}$. Let $g: \mathcal{N} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}^{\prime}$ be a map from $\mathcal{N}$ to a smooth manifold $\mathcal{N}^{\prime}$. If $g \circ f$ is differentiable, then $g$ is also differentiable.
A.2. Submanifolds. Let $h: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}$ be any map and $c$ be any point of $\mathcal{N}$. We call the set $h^{-1}(c)$ a level set of $h$. Let $h$ be a smooth map between smooth manifolds $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$. A point $x \in \mathcal{M}$ is said to be a regular point of $h$ if the differential $d_{x} h: \mathcal{T}_{x} \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathcal{T}_{h(x)} \mathcal{N}$ is surjective. A level set $h^{-1}(c)$ is called a regular level set if every element in $h^{-1}(c)$ is a regular point of $h$. Proposition A. 2 shows that every regular level set is an embedded submanifold.

Proposition A. 2 ([33], Corollary 5.14). Every regular level set of a smooth map between smooth manifolds is a properly embedded submanifold.

Suppose $\mathcal{S}$ is a regular level set of a smooth map $h: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$, and is treated as an embedded submanifold of $\mathcal{M}$. Proposition A. 3 characterizes the tangent space of $\mathcal{S}$ at each point as a subspace of the tangent space of $\mathcal{M}$ at the same point.

Proposition A. 3 ([33], Corollary 5.39). Suppose $\mathcal{M}$ is a smooth manifold and $\mathcal{S} \subseteq \mathcal{M}$ is an embedded submanifold. Suppose $\mathcal{S}$ is a level set of a smooth submersion $h: \mathcal{M} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$. For $p \in \mathcal{S}$, a vector $v \in T_{p} \mathcal{M}$ is tangent to $\mathcal{S}$ if and only if $d_{p} h(v)=0$.
A.3. Lie group actions. To employ the quotient manifold theorem [33], one needs to study the properties of Lie group actions. One useful tool is the following proposition.

Proposition A. 4 ([33], Corollary 21.6). Every continuous action by a compact Lie group on a manifold is proper.

Appendix B. Omitted proofs. In this section, we provide the proofs that are omitted from the main text. For readers' convenience, we will restate the propositions.

# B.1. Proof of Proposition 3.2. 

Proposition B.1. The metric spaces $(\operatorname{Corr}(m,[k]), d^{\text {orb }, k})$ and $(\operatorname{Corr}(m,[k]), d^{\mathrm{E}})$ share the same topology.

Proof. We prove this proposition in two steps.

- First, we claim that when

$$
X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top} \text { in } d^{\mathrm{orb}, k}, \quad \text { where } X_{n}, X \in \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}
$$

it holds that $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\mathrm{E}}$. Indeed, when $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\text {orb }, k}$, it implies that there exists $\widetilde{X}_{n} \in\left[X_{n}\right]$ such that $\widetilde{X}_{n} \rightarrow X$ in $d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k}$. Note that $\left(\Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}, d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k}\right)$ has the same topology as $\left(\Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}, d^{\mathrm{E}, k}\right)$, where $d^{\mathrm{E}, k}$ is the Euclidean distance in $\mathbb{R}^{m \times k}$. It implies that $\widetilde{X}_{n} \rightarrow X$ in $d^{\mathrm{E}, k}$. Since the map

$$
\phi_{k}: \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}, \quad Y \rightarrow Y Y^{\top}
$$

is continuous, we conclude that $\widetilde{X}_{n} \widetilde{X}_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\mathrm{E}}$. The first claim then follows from the fact that $\widetilde{X}_{n} \in\left[X_{n}\right]$ and $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top}=\widetilde{X}_{n} \widetilde{X}_{n}^{\top}$.

- Next, we claim that when

$$
X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top} \text { in } d^{\mathrm{E}}, \quad \text { where } X_{n}, X \in \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}
$$

it holds that $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\text {orb }, k}$. Indeed, when $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\mathrm{E}}$, we have $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\mathrm{BW}}$ as $\left(\operatorname{Cov}(m), d^{\mathrm{E}}\right)$ and $\left(\operatorname{Cov}(m), d^{\mathrm{BW}}\right)$ have the same topology [61], where $d^{\mathrm{BW}}$ is the Bures-Wasserstein distance in $\operatorname{Cov}(m)$. Proposition 5.1 in [39] implies that there exists $\widetilde{X}_{n} \in\left[X_{n}\right]$ such that $\widetilde{X}_{n} \rightarrow X$ in $d^{\mathrm{E}, k}$. Thus, $\widetilde{X}_{n} \rightarrow X$ in $d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k}$, as $\left(\Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}, d^{\mathrm{E}, k}\right)$ and $\left(\Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}, d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k}\right)$ have the same topology. Therefore, $\widetilde{X}_{n} \widetilde{X}_{n}^{\top} \rightarrow X X^{\top}$ in $d^{\text {orb }, k}$, and the second claim holds since $X_{n} X_{n}^{\top}=\widetilde{X}_{n} \widetilde{X}_{n}^{\top}$.
Combining these two steps, we conclude the proof of this proposition.

# B.2. Proof of Proposition 3.3. 

Proposition B.2. $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ is a smooth embedded submanifold of $\mathbb{R}^{m \times m}$. The bijection $\Phi_{k, \ell}$ in (3.2) is a diffeomorphism between two smooth manifolds.

Proof. First, we establish the smooth structure of $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ by utilizing its relationship with $\operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell)$, which has been shown to be a smooth embedded submanifold of $\mathbb{R}^{m \times m}$ [64]. The tangent space of $\operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell)$ at $Z \in \operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell)$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{T}_{Z} \operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell)=\left\{\Delta Z+Z \Delta^{\top} \mid \Delta \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}\right\}
$$

Consider the smooth map

$$
\operatorname{diag}_{m, \ell}: \operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}, \quad Z \rightarrow \operatorname{diag}(Z)
$$

where $\operatorname{diag}(Z)$ is a vector consisting of the diagonal elements of $Z$, defined in Section 1.1. Let $c$ be an $m$-dimensional vector whose entries are all 1 . Then the set $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ is a level set of $\operatorname{diag}_{m, \ell}$ in the sense that $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)=\operatorname{diag}_{m, \ell}^{-1}(c)$. For $Z \in \operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell)$, the differential $d_{Z}\left(\operatorname{diag}_{m, \ell}\right): \mathcal{T}_{Z} \operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell) \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$ is given by

$$
V \rightarrow \operatorname{diag}(V), \quad V=\Delta Z+Z \Delta^{\top} \in \mathcal{T}_{Z} \operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell), \quad \Delta \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}
$$

Therefore, the differential is surjective when $Z \in \operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$. Consequently, $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ is a regular level set of $\operatorname{diag}_{m, \ell}$ and by Proposition A.2, $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ is a smooth embedded submanifold of $\operatorname{Cov}(m, \ell)$. In particular, it is a smooth embedded submanifold of

$\mathbb{R}^{m \times m}$. By Proposition A.3, the tangent space of $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ at each point $Z$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{T}_{Z} \operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)=\left\{\Delta Z+Z \Delta^{\top} \mid \Delta \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}, \operatorname{diag}(\Delta Z)=0\right\}
$$

When $Z=Y Y^{\top}$ for $Y \in \Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{\ell-1}$, we can provide a concise characterization of this tangent space. Let $Y_{\perp} \in \operatorname{St}(m, m-\ell)$ be an orthonormal matrix such that $Y_{\perp}^{\top} Y=\mathbf{0}$. Then we can rewrite $\Delta \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}$ as follows:

$$
\Delta=\xi\left(Y^{\top} Y\right)^{-1} Y^{\top}+\zeta Y_{\perp}^{\top}
$$

where $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times \ell}$ and $\zeta \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times(m-\ell)}$. Using this representation, we have

$$
\Delta Z+Z \Delta^{\top}=\xi Y^{\top}+Y \xi^{\top}
$$

Substituting it into (B.2), we can rewrite the tangent space in (B.2) as

$$
\mathcal{T}_{Z} \operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)=\left\{\xi Y^{\top}+Y \xi^{\top} \mid \xi \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times \ell}, \operatorname{diag}\left(\xi Y^{\top}\right)=\mathbf{0}\right\}
$$

We will use this characterization in the following proof.
Now we show that the bijection $\Phi_{k, \ell}$ in (3.2) is a diffeomorphism between smooth manifolds $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$ and $\Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1} / \mathcal{O}(k)$. Define the map

$$
\phi_{k, \ell}: \Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1} \rightarrow \operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell), \quad X \rightarrow X X^{\top}
$$

It holds that $\phi_{k, \ell}=\Phi_{k, \ell} \circ \pi_{k, \ell}$ and $\pi_{k, \ell}=\Phi_{k, \ell}^{-1} \circ \phi_{k, \ell}$, where $\pi_{k, \ell}$ is given in (3.7). By Proposition A.1, if we show that $\pi_{k, \ell}$ and $\phi_{k, \ell}$ are both smooth submersions, then it implies that $\Phi_{k, \ell}$ and $\Phi_{k, \ell}^{-1}$ are both differentiable and thus $\Phi_{k, \ell}$ is a diffeomorphism.

Recall that $\pi_{k, \ell}$ is a smooth submersion. It remains to show that $\phi_{k, \ell}$ is a smooth submersion. Since $\phi_{k, \ell}$ is a surjective smooth map, it suffices to show that the differential $d_{X}\left(\phi_{k, \ell}\right)$ at any $X \in \Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}$ is surjective. Here the differential map is given by

$$
d_{X}\left(\phi_{k, \ell}\right): \mathcal{T}_{X} \Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1} \rightarrow \mathcal{T}_{\phi_{k, \ell}(X)} \operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell), \quad W \rightarrow W X^{\top}+X W^{\top}
$$

The space $\Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}$ can be rewritten as

$$
\Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}=\left\{Y U^{\top} \mid Y \in \Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{\ell-1}, U \in \operatorname{St}(k, \ell)\right\}
$$

The tangent space of $\Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}$ at each point $X=Y U^{\top}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{T}_{X} \Pi_{\ell}^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k-1}= & \left\{T U^{\top}+Y K^{\top} \mid T \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times \ell}, \operatorname{diag}\left(Y T^{\top}\right)=\mathbf{0}\right. \\
& \left.K \in \mathbb{R}^{k \times \ell}, U^{\top} K+K^{\top} U=\mathbf{0}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, for $X=Y U^{\top}$ in (B.5) and $W=T U^{\top}+Y K^{\top}$ in (B.6), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{X}\left(\phi_{k, \ell}\right)(W) & =\left(T U^{\top}+Y K^{\top}\right)\left(Y U^{\top}\right)^{\top}+Y U^{\top}\left(T U^{\top}+Y K^{\top}\right)^{\top} \\
& =T Y^{\top}+Y T^{\top}
\end{aligned}
$$

By the characterization (B.3) of the tangent space of $\operatorname{Corr}(m, \ell)$, we conclude that the differential $d_{X}\left(\phi_{k, \ell}\right)$ is surjective. This completes the proof.

# B.3. Proof of Proposition 3.6. 

Proposition B.3. Let $d^{\text {orb }, k}$ be the distance in the orbit space $\operatorname{Corr}(m,[k])$. For $k_{1}<k_{2} \leq m$, we have

$$
d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}\left(Z_{1}, Z_{2}\right) \leq d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}\left(Z_{1}, Z_{2}\right), \quad \forall Z_{1}, Z_{2} \in \operatorname{Corr}\left(m,\left[k_{1}\right]\right)
$$

Moreover, $d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}$ and $d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}$ are different, even when constrained to $\operatorname{Corr}\left(m,\left[k_{1}\right]\right)$.
Proof. Let $k_{1}<k_{2} \leq m$. First, we show that

$$
d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}\left(Z_{1}, Z_{2}\right) \leq d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}\left(Z_{1}, Z_{2}\right), \quad \forall Z_{1}, Z_{2} \in \operatorname{Corr}\left(m,\left[k_{1}\right]\right)
$$

Let $X, Y \in \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k_{1}-1}$ and set $\widetilde{X}=[X \mathbf{0}], \widetilde{Y}=[Y \mathbf{0}] \in \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k_{2}-1}$. The distances $d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}$ and $d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}\left(X X^{\top}, Y Y^{\top}\right)\right)^{2} & =\inf _{O \in \mathcal{O}\left(k_{1}\right)} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \arccos ^{2}\left(\left\langle(X O)_{i} ., Y_{i} .\right\rangle\right) \\
\left(d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}\left(X X^{\top}, Y Y^{\top}\right)\right)^{2} & =\inf _{\widetilde{O} \in \mathcal{O}\left(k_{2}\right)} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \arccos ^{2}\left(\left\langle(\widetilde{X} \widetilde{O})_{i} ., \widetilde{Y}_{i} .\right\rangle\right) \\
& =\inf _{U \in \mathcal{A}} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \arccos ^{2}\left(\left\langle(X U)_{i} ., Y_{i} .\right\rangle\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{A}$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{A}=\left\{U \in \mathbb{R}^{k_{1} \times k_{1}} \mid \exists \widetilde{O} \in \mathcal{O}\left(k_{2}\right) \text { such that } U=\widetilde{O}_{\left[1: k_{1}\right],\left[1: k_{1}\right]}\right\}
$$

Since $\mathcal{O}\left(k_{1}\right)$ is a subset of $\mathcal{A}$, we have

$$
d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}\left(X X^{\top}, Y Y^{\top}\right) \geq d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}\left(X X^{\top}, Y Y^{\top}\right)
$$

This proves the first part of the proposition.
Now we demonstrate that $d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}}$ is different from $d^{\text {orb }, k_{2}}$. Due to the monotone property we have proved, it suffices to consider the case where $k_{2}=k_{1}+1$. We use examples to prove the claim. Specifically, let

$$
X=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
-1 & \mathbf{0} \\
1 & \mathbf{0} \\
\mathbf{0} & W
\end{array}\right), Y=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \mathbf{0} \\
1 & \mathbf{0} \\
\mathbf{0} & W
\end{array}\right) \in \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k_{1}-1}
$$

where $W \in \Pi_{k_{1}-1}^{m-2} \mathbb{S}^{k_{1}-2}$ is of rank $k_{1}-1$. Also, let

$$
\widetilde{X}=(\mathbf{0}, X), \widetilde{Y}=(\mathbf{0}, Y) \in \Pi^{m} \mathbb{S}^{k_{1}}
$$

Let

$$
O^{* *}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 1 & \mathbf{0} \\
1 & 0 & \mathbf{0} \\
\mathbf{0} & \mathbf{0} & I_{k_{1}-1}
\end{array}\right) \in \mathcal{O}\left(k_{1}+1\right)
$$

Then by definition, the distance $d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}+1}(\widetilde{X}, \widetilde{Y})$ is smaller than

$$
d^{\text {orb }, k_{1}+1}\left(\widetilde{X} \widetilde{X}^{\top}, \widetilde{Y} \widetilde{Y}^{\top}\right) \leq d^{\Pi \mathbb{S}, k_{1}+1}\left(\widetilde{X} O^{* *}, \widetilde{Y}\right)=\pi / \sqrt{2}
$$

In the meanwhile, since $\mathcal{O}\left(k_{1}\right)$ is a compact set, we can express $d^{\text {arb }, k_{1}}(\cdot, \cdot)$ as follows:

$$
d^{\text {arb }, k_{1}}\left(X X^{\top}, Y Y^{\top}\right)=d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k_{1}}\left(X O^{*}, Y\right)
$$

for some $O^{*} \in \mathcal{O}\left(k_{1}\right)$. There are two cases:

- First, $O_{11}^{*} \neq 0$, where $O_{11}^{*}$ is the $(1,1)$-th element of $O^{*}$. In this case,

$$
d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k_{1}}\left(X O^{*}, Y\right) \geq \sqrt{\arccos ^{2}\left(O_{11}^{*}\right)+\arccos ^{2}\left(-O_{11}^{*}\right)}>\pi / \sqrt{2}
$$

- Second, $O_{11}^{*}=0$. In this case, we denote $O_{2 ; 2}^{*}$, the $\left(2: k_{1}, 2: k_{1}\right)$-th submatrix of $O^{*}$. Since $O^{*}$ is an orthogonal matrix and $O_{11}^{*}=0$, we conclude that $O_{2 ; 2}^{*}$, is not equal to $I_{k_{1}-1}$. As a result, we have

$$
d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k_{1}-1}\left(W O_{2 ; 2 ;}^{*}, W\right)>0
$$

where we use the condition that $W$ is full rank (i.e., $\operatorname{rank}\left(k_{1}-1\right)$ ). Then, by definition,

$$
d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k_{1}}\left(X O^{*}, Y\right) \geq \sqrt{\pi^{2} / 2+\left(d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k_{1}-1}\left(W O_{2 ; 2 ;}^{*}, W\right)\right)^{2}}>\pi / \sqrt{2}
$$

Combining these two cases, we obtain

$$
d^{\text {arb }, k_{1}}\left(X X^{\top}, Y Y^{\top}\right)=d^{\mathrm{IIS}, k_{1}}\left(X O^{*}, Y\right)>\pi / \sqrt{2} \geq d^{\text {arb }, k_{1}+1}\left(\widehat{X} \widehat{X}^{\top}, \widehat{Y} \widehat{Y}^{\top}\right)
$$

This concludes the proof, since $X X^{\top}=\widehat{X} \widehat{X}^{\top}$ and $Y Y^{\top}=\widehat{Y} \widehat{Y}^{\top}$.

abstract:
This paper studies the quotient geometry of bounded or fixed-rank correlation
matrices. We establish a bijection between the set of bounded-rank correlation
matrices and a quotient set of a spherical product manifold by an orthogonal
group. We show that it forms an orbit space, whose stratification is determined
by the rank of the matrices, and the principal stratum has a compatible
Riemannian quotient manifold structure. We show that any minimizing geodesic in
the orbit space has constant rank on the interior of the segment. We also
develop efficient Riemannian optimization algorithms for computing the distance
and weighted the Frechet mean in the orbit space. Moreover, we examine
geometric properties of the quotient manifold, including horizontal and
vertical spaces, Riemannian metric, injectivity radius, exponential and
logarithmic map, curvature, gradient and Hessian. Finally, we apply our
approach to a functional connectivity study using the Autism Brain Imaging Data
Exchange.
